source: Newsletter – Inspired by freeCodeCamp Weekly Newsletter and Dev.to Weekly

level_1: Newsletters explain why having a portfolio is important for any software developer.
They describe what a portfolio means: a collection of real coding projects shared online.
In this module, students learn how to make simple projects and upload them publicly.
The newsletter gives motivation and stories about beginners who got hired because they had a clear GitHub profile.
It reminds you that even one or two well-finished projects can help you stand out.
level_2: These newsletters often give step-by-step checklists on what to include in your project README files.
They explain how to pick a project idea that shows your real skills, not just tutorials.
This module covers writing simple explanations of what your code does, so anyone can understand it.
The newsletter explains how adding screenshots and usage instructions makes your repo look professional.
It also suggests tools and websites to host your portfolio for free.
level_3: At this level, newsletters share how to make niche or advanced projects that highlight unique skills.
They give advice on contributing to open source projects as part of your portfolio strategy.
In this module, students learn to keep their code clean, organized, and easy to reuse.
The newsletter shares examples of how to connect your GitHub projects to your LinkedIn profile or website.
It also explains why recruiters trust clean, active GitHub profiles more than random resumes.
level_4: For expert learners, newsletters give ideas on building community projects that attract contributors.
They explain how senior devs use portfolios to show leadership, not just code.
This module pushes students to update old projects regularly, fix issues, and accept feedback from peers.
Newsletters share best practices for maintaining popular repos over years.
They encourage students to guide juniors on how to create and share good projects too.
